questions.text: Identify the formula given below:
questions.solution:
The formula given above is used to calculate the standard deviation.

Standard deviation (or σ) is a measure of how dispersed the data is in relation to the mean. Data clustered around the mean have a low standard deviation, while data that are more spread out have a high standard deviation. A standard deviation close to zero indicates that data points are close to the mean, whereas a high or low standard deviation indicates data points are respectively above or below the mean.

Standard error = SD/√n, where SD is the standard deviation and n is the sample size

Standard error will reduce when the sample size is increased.

The median divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores. 

Variance is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation?

1. Goodell's sign
2. Osiander's sign
3. Internal ballottement
4. Lightening
questions.solution:
The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign and Osiander's sign.

Goodell’s sign is a sign of early pregnancy, which describes the marked softening of the cervix in contrast to the non-pregnant state. It is seen as early as the 6th week. 

Osiander's sign describes the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity. It is seen around 8 weeks of gestation.

Internal ballottement can be elicited between 16–28th weeks of gestation, before which the fetus is too small and after which it is too large to displace. It may not be elicited in cases with scanty liquor amnii, or when the fetus is transversely placed.

Lightening is a sense of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part. It is felt at about 38 weeks of gestation.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except:

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.solution:
The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all except protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

Oral hormonal contraceptives can be combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) or progesterone-only minipills.

COCPs are a combination of ethinylestradiol at a dose of 20–30 mcg and an orally active progestogen. It is taken starting on the first day of the cycle for 21 days. They are taken at a fixed time of the day, preferably after a meal. Mala-N and Mala-D both contain levonorgestrel (0.15 mg) + ethinylestradiol (30 mcg). Mala-N is supplied free of cost in Family Planning Clinics in India. Each strip contains 21 hormonal tablets and 7 non-hormonal (iron) tablets. 

The mechanism of action is the prevention of ovulation by suppression of the pituitary hormones FSH and LH. Progesterone also acts on the cervical mucus, making it thick and impenetrable by sperm. The pregnancy rate with the COCP is 0.3 per 100 woman-years.

Benefits of the COCP:

  • It is effective in controlling fertility.
  • It causes regular cycles and reduces menstrual blood loss and are, therefore, useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhea.
  • It lowers the incidence of benign breast neoplastic diseases, such as fibrocystic disease.
  • It reduces the incidence of functional ovarian cysts and ovarian (Option A) and endometrial malignancy (Option D). The incidence of ovarian cancer is reduced by 40% and that of uterine malignancy, by 50%, if taken for 1 year; this effect lasts as long as 10 years after stoppage.
  • It reduces the incidence of ectopic pregnancy (Option B) by suppressing ovulation and reducing the risk in pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • It is useful in endometriosis, acne, and polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD).

Side effects:

  • Higher incidence of breast cancer reported among users
  • Suppression of lactation
  • Occurrence of pituitary adenoma and adenoma of the liver
  • Reduced carbohydrate tolerance (therefore, contraindicated in diabetic women)
  • Migraine, depression, weight gain, and lethargy (due to progesterone)
  • Increased risk of pulmonary embolism and cerebral thrombosis

Ninety-nine percent of women will regain normal menstrual cycles within 6 months of stopping the pills, while the return of fertility is slightly delayed.

Barrier methods like condoms prevent the transmission of STDs.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with chronic stable angina, presenting with fatigue and brownish-colored blood is suggestive of methemoglobinemia. For the management of chronic stable angina, she must be taking nitrates and methemoglobinemia is a rare complication of nitrate (isosorbide) consumption.

Nitrate ions released during the metabolism of isosorbide oxidize hemoglobin (Fe2+) to the brown methemoglobin (Fe3+), thereby producing methemoglobinemia. The risk of developing clinically significant methemoglobinemia is higher in patients with coronary ischemia and anemia.

Interestingly, pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and irrespective of the methemoglobin levels. Co-oximeters that can differentiate methemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, and deoxyhemoglobin are thus preferred for the diagnosis of methemoglobinemia.

Treatment of methemoglobinemia associated with isosorbide toxicity involves supportive care, cessation of isosorbide consumption, and reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg).

Other options: 

Option A: Carboxy-hemoglobinemia occurs due to acute and chronic carbon monoxide intoxication through occupational exposure and exposure to incompletely burned hydrocarbons. It presents with headache, altered mental status, and other constitutional symptoms.

Option B: Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia that occurs in the presence of normal to high levels of iron. The characteristic ring sideroblasts are seen in the peripheral smear. Causes of sideroblastic anemia include pyridoxine deficiency, lead poisoning, and alcoholism.

Option D: Sulfhemoglobinemia is a rare irreversible condition that can occur with the ingestion of drugs such as dapsone and sulphonamides.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s clinical features are strongly suggestive of Turner syndrome.

Turner's syndrome is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. The classical karyotype is 45, XO. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females.

The clinical features of Turner’s syndrome include short stature, short webbed neck, shield chest with widely spaced nipples, primary amenorrhea, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies. Two X chromosomes are required for the development of ovaries. The loss of one X chromosome results in streak ovaries with inadequate estrogen production. The loss of negative feedback from reduced estrogen raises the FSH and LH levels causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other options:

Option B: Kallmnann syndrome presents with delayed puberty due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism from deficiency of GnRH. It is associated with olfactory dysfunction and anosmia.

Option C: Androgen insensitivity syndrome occurs due to a defect in the androgen receptor in a genotypic male (XY). These individuals are phenotypic females with no male or female internal genitalia. They have normal female external genitalia with an absent or shallow vagina, well-developed breasts, and scanty body hair (axillary and pubic) and are present with primary amenorrhea.

Option D: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, commonly referred to as Mullerian agenesis, has primary amenorrhea due to failure of development of the uterus, cervix, and upper vagina. They have normally functioning gonads and external genitalia.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Yes

Karyotype

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text:
A patient presented with ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensations in the face, vertigo with numbness and loss of sweating and dysarthria on the contralateral side. All these symptoms are caused due to a lesion in:

A. Medial medulla
B. Lateral medulla
C. Ventromedial medulla
D. Lateral medulla including nucleus ambiguus and spinothalamic tract
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the ipsilateral vertebral artery.

Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).
 

The lateral medullary syndrome may also occur as a consequence of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) stroke. PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Identify the liver segment marked in the image below:
questions.solution:
The liver segment highlighted in green in this CT section is segment V. The section of the CT given is taken below the portal vein as the cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation can be viewed.

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments: 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment IVb below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIII above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral) section: segment VII above and segment VI below the portal plane

 Shown below is a section from below the portal plane.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: A female presented with loss of pain and temperature, but her touch sensation was intact. Imaging showed cavitation around the central canal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image showing cavitation around the central canal is syringomyelia. 

Syringomyelia is a progressive disease of the spinal cord in which there is an enlarging cavity in the cord. Syrinx cavities are acquired cavities of the cord in necrosed areas secondary to trauma, myelitis, and spinal cord tumors. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with central cord symptoms. 

Most patients present with regional dissociated sensory loss of pain and temperature of the upper limbs. Touch and vibration senses are intact. The loss of sensation has a 'cape distribution' affecting the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. Eventually, expansion of the cavity may lead to compression of the long tracts. This results in spasticity and weakness of the legs, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome. 

MRI is used for the diagnosis. There is no satisfactory treatment for this condition. Symptomatic syrinx cavities secondary to trauma or infection, are treated with a decompression and drainage procedure.

Other options: 

Option A: Brown-Sequard syndrome occurs due to the transection of the spinal cord only on one side. This results in ipsilateral weakness and loss of joint position and vibration sensation with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

Option B: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of neurosyphilis, which occur within a year or up to 10-35 years after primary infection. It causes demyelination of the dorsal column of the spinal cord and presents with bladder disturbances, foot drop, impotence, and ataxia. Loss of position and vibration sense result in a positive Romberg test.

Option C: Syringobulbia occurs when the syrinx of syringomyelia extends into the medulla. It is characterized by palatal or vocal cord paralysis, episodic vertigo, tongue weakness with atrophy, and horizontal nystagmus. 

Related Pearl: Extent of important structures/spaces in the Spinal cord

Structure / Space  Terminal extent 
Spinal cord at birth  L3 upper border 
Spinal cord at 2 years  L1 lower border 
Adult Spinal cord  L1 lower border  
Filum terminale  1st coccygeal segment 
Filum terminale internum , Dural sac S2 lower border 
Filum terminale externum  1st coccygeal segment 
Piamater  1st coccygeal segment 
Subarachnoid sheath and space, Subdural space  S2 lower border 
Cervical enlargement  C3-T2 spinal segments 
Lumbar enlargement  L1-S3 spinal segments 

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding central venous access and peripheral venous access?
  1. Phlebitis is the most common complication in peripheral venous access.
  2. Isotonic saline and heparin are flushed to retain patency.
  3. If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, avoid peripheral venous access in the same limb.
  4. Vasopressors for septic shock are given in the central line to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
All the given statements are true regarding central and peripheral venous catheters.

Peripheral intravenous cannulation is the insertion of a single-lumen plastic conduit across the skin into a peripheral vein. They are used in the transfusion of fluids, medications, and other therapies such as blood products. Phlebitis is the most common complication in peripheral venous access (Statement 1). Relative contraindications are coagulopathy, local infection, burns, arteriovenous fistula (Statement 3), or deep venous thrombosis on the affected limb.

Central venous catheter insertion is used in critically ill patients. It is inserted into a large, central vein. The most common veins are the internal jugular and subclavian veins. It is used in case of multiple infusions incompatible with peripheral intravenous access, and hemodynamic monitoring. Vasopressors are an integral component in the management of septic shock and are given in the central line (Statement 4).

To prevent or avoid the formation of thrombus in venous catheters, the solutions used include 0.9% sodium chloride, heparin (Statement 2), vitamin C, and sodium citrate.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

17G White 125ml/min Newly added
18G Green 103 ml/min Blood products, delivery of irritant medications, major surgery, contrast study
20G Pink 67ml/min General use IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, IV analgesics
22G Blue 42 ml/min Small or Fragile veins, Cytotoxic Therapy
24G Yellow 20ml/min For pediatric Usage
26G Violet 13ml/min Newly added

questions.text: A patient was treated for peptic ulcer with an H.pylori regimen. Which of the following is used to assess the success of treatment?
questions.solution:
The success of treatment after H.pylori can be assessed by the urea breath test.

Peptic ulcer disease is most likely caused by Helicobacter pylori. H. pylori is a gram-negative motile bacillus. It has a unique feature of producing urease which is helpful in diagnosis. The sole source of H. pylori is the human gastric mucus. H.pylori causes chronic superficial gastritis on long-term colonization. Only a few people develop peptic ulceration, gastric adenocarcinoma, and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

Diagnosis can be made by tests based on endoscopic biopsy:

  1. Biopsy urease test, which is quick and simple (Option D)
  2. Histology can give additional information.
  3. Culture can determine antibiotic susceptibility.

Non-invasive tests:

  1. Serology tests (Option B: IgG antibody study) are inexpensive and convenient but cannot be used to monitor treatment success.
  2. 13C Urea breath test requires fasting but is useful for follow-up.
  3. Stool antigen test is useful, particularly in children, and is also useful for follow-up.

The urea breath test is used to assess the success of treatment as it is non-invasive and less expensive than endoscopy. However, because this test is dependent on H. pylori load, use in less than 4 weeks after treatment may yield false-negative results. Endoscopy and a biopsy-based test are also used in follow-up after treatment. The main indication for these invasive tests is to exclude underlying gastric adenocarcinoma in a case of gastric ulcer.

Current treatment regimens consist of a proton-pump inhibitor (omeprazole) and two or three antimicrobial agents given for 10–14 days.

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest x-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infrascapular region?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray and symptoms are suggestive of pleural effusion secondary to a lower respiratory tract infection. On examination, dullness to percussion will be observed.

Pleural effusion refers to the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space due to

  • excess fluid formation from the interstitial spaces of the lung, parietal pleura, or peritoneal cavity
  • decreased fluid removal by the lymphatics

Pleural effusion may present with dyspnea, pleuritic pain, dry cough, and associated symptoms like fever, weight loss, edema, and ascites depending on the etiology. On examination, there may be tachypnea, dullness on percussion and decreased/absent breath sounds at the base(s).

The etiology of pleural effusion can be of two types:

  • Exudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage because of local factors. Examples include malignancy, infections, and pulmonary embolism.
  • Transudative: disruption in pleural fluid formation and drainage due to systemic factors. Examples include congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.

Option A: Hyperresonance is a sign of pneumothorax or emphysema.

Option B: Crackles are heard in cases of pulmonary edema or pneumonia.

Option D: Stridor is due to a lesion in the upper airways, usually tracheal or laryngeal.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of keratoconus?
questions.solution:
The incorrect about keratoconus is Haab's striae. Haab's striae are seen in cases of buphthalmos where the intraocular pressure is raised and the eyeball is enlarged as a whole. The enlarged cornea is associated with tears in Descemet's membrane called Haab's striae.

Keratoconus or the conical cornea is a bilateral non-inflammatory progressive condition of the axial part of the cornea. Central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea are pathognomonic. This is attributed to mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissue synthesis defects. 

Clinical features of the condition include defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism. Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present. Complications include acute hydrops following the rupture of Descemet's membrane.

Slit-lamp examination reveals Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone formed. Deep, vertical stromal striae (Vogt lines) that disappear with external pressure are characteristic. Retinoscopy shows a scissoring reflex. The bulging of the lower lid in the downgaze, called Munson's sign, is shown in the image below.

The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry. Corneal topography is a diagnostic modality with the highest sensitivity for early cases.

Intacs or intracorneal ring segments are useful in moderate cases due to their flattening effect. Rigid gas-permeable contact lenses, corneal collagen cross-linking with riboflavin, and keratoplasty are the other treatment modalities.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department with a history of assault by a mob using heavy blunt objects and sharp objects. On examination, crushing of the hair bulb was seen. Identify the type of wound.
questions.solution:
The type of wound in which the crushing of the hair bulb is seen is a lacerated wound.

Cut lacerations may be produced by blunt weapons or heavy relatively sharp-edged weapons such as axe, hatchets, and choppers. Scalp lacerations can be found in association with bruising and abrasions. Fascial strands, hair bulbs, nerves, and vessels, that run in the depth of the wound, are irregularly torn and crushed.

Margins are irregular, ragged, and uneven. The ends are pointed or blunt. The edges of lacerations, especially over the skull are undermined. The depth of the wound varies according to the thickness of the soft parts at the site of the injury and the degree of force applied.

Medicolegal importance of laceration:

  • The type of laceration indicates the cause of the injury and the shape of the weapon.
  • Foreign bodies found in the wound may indicate the circumstances in which the crime was committed.
  • The age of the injury can be determined.
The image below shows a lacerated wound.

Other options

Option A: An incised wound is clean-cut, regular, and well-defined. Bruising does not occur when caused by light-cutting weapons but bruising and some irregularity of the margins may be present when heavy and not-so-sharp-edged weapons like a shovel, Kassi, axe, tangi, etc. have been used.

Option C: Chop wounds are caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, or hatchet. The margins of the wound depending on the condition of the weapon, a sharp margin with slight bruising is seen with a sharp-edged weapon, and a ragged and bruised margin is seen with a blunt edge. Undermining occurs in the direction towards which the chop is made.

Option D: Avulsion or shearing laceration is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues. It is due to shearing force delivered at an acute angle. Commonly seen in road traffic accidents.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change given in the image.
questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown above is marbling, which is an external sign of putrefaction.

In marbling, the superficial veins of roots of the limb, thighs, sides of the abdomen, and shoulders are stained greenish-brown or purplish-red, in a linear branching pattern. It is usually prominent 36–48 hours after death occurs due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin subsequent to hemolysis of red blood cells.

In putrefaction, bacteria from the gut enter into and multiply in the surrounding tissues, eventually spreading through the blood vessels to other parts of the body. The bacterium Clostridium welchii is largely responsible for the putrefactive changes spreading through the body, due to its production of the enzyme lecithinase. The first external sign of putrefaction in a body lying outside in the air is a greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the cecum.

Other options:

Option B: Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is due to the deposition of unburnt powder particles. These are difficult to remove. They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing

Option C: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the dermis. It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to the stagnation of blood in the vessels of the dependent parts due to the effect of gravity. 

Option D: Filigree burns also known as Lichtenberg's flowers are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.

questions.text:
Match the following cell types with their associated malignancy.
1. Popcorn cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
2. Faggot cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
3. Cerebriform nuclei c. Burkitt lymphoma
4. Starry sky d. Sezary syndrome
questions.solution:
The correct matches are as follows:

1. Popcorn cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
2. Faggot cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
3. Cerebriform nuclei d. Sezary syndrome
4. Starry sky c. Burkitt lymphoma

 

Popcorn cell is a lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed Steenberg (RS) cells that are characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. It has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn. The image below shows a popcorn cell seen in lymphocytic predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks are known as faggot cells and are highly suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals numerous Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes. Faggot cells are shown below.

Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).

The histological hallmark of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fungoides type) is the presence of Sezary-Lutzner cells, which form band-like aggregates within the superficial dermis and invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters called Pautrier microabscess (marked by arrow). These cells have markedly infolded nuclear membranes giving them a cerebriform contour as seen below.

Microscopy in Burkitt lymphoma shows a characteristic starry sky pattern. The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with frequent mitotic figures and reactive macrophages scattered through the tumor, with their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumor cells giving the tumor a so-called "starry sky" appearance.

The image given below shows a starry sky pattern seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Variants of Reed Sternberg Cells

Variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's Lymphoma

  • Lacunar Variant: Nodular Sclerosis
  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 
  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

Related Pearl: Types of giant cells

Giant cells Seen in
Langhans giant cells TB Granuloma
Reed Sternberg cells Hodgkin lymphoma
Aschoff giant cells Rheumatic fever
Touton giant cells

Juvenile xanthogranuloma,

Xanthoma disseminatum,

dermatofibroma
Warthin Finkeldey giant cells Measles
Physiological giant cells Bone marrow osteoclast cells and megakaryocytes

questions.text: A male patient working in the matchbox industry for the past 20 years reports to the dentist with multiple sinuses and fistulae in and around his jaw with foul-smelling discharge. Which of the following chemicals are responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a phossy jaw, which occurs due to chronic phosphorus poisoning. Phossy jaw refers to osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses.

Frequent inhalation of phosphorus fumes causes necrosis of the lower jaw in the region of a decayed tooth. Patients initially present with toothache, followed by swelling of the jaw, loosening of the teeth, necrosis of gums, and sequestration of the bone in the mandible producing considerable facial disfigurement. 

Chronic phosphorus poisoning is common among the workers of phosphorus industries (matchbox factories), who have had chronic exposure to phosphorus fumes for months to years. It is managed surgically and by prevention of further exposure to the poison. 

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms, white phosphorus, a highly toxic form, and red phosphorus, the non-toxic form. 

Fulminant poisoning is seen when more than one gram is consumed, and death occurs within 12 hours due to peripheral vascular collapse. In acute poisoning, they present with pain in the throat and abdomen, with intense thirst, nausea, diarrhea, and severe abdominal pain. System toxicity occurs after 2–3 days and results in hematemesis, enlarged tender liver, jaundice, pruritus, and hemorrhages. The gastric and intestinal content have garlic odor and are luminous.

Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb the poison. 

Other options:

Option A: Bromine is a corrosive substance that causes necrosis of skin and tissues.

Option B: The symptoms of antimony poisoning, both acute and chronic are similar to that of arsenic. Inhalation of fumes causes a flu-like illness called metal fume fever. In cases of chronic poisoning with heavy metals such as lead, arsenic, mercury, antimony, copper, etc., the shaft of a long bone, strands of scalp hair, fingernails or toenails, and a wedge of the quadriceps muscle should be taken for sampling. 

Option C: Prolonged ingestion of fluorides results in the mottling of teeth, an increase in the density of bones, lipping of bony margins of vertebrae, which sometimes produce pressure on the spinal cord leading to paraplegia.

Related Pearl: Phosphorus poisoning

Features

Phosphorus
Chemistry

2 forms - White and Red Phosphorus

White Phosphorus is toxic, Red Phosphorus is not.
Mechanism of action Protoplasmic irritant poison
Organs affected

Liver

Bone

Kidneys

Smoky stool syndrome

Luminescent stools

Garlicky odor

questions.text: On inoculation in the skin, all of the following organisms can lead to dermal, subcutaneous, and lymphatic involvement except_____
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics characteristic of sporotrichoid lymphcutaneous infection. All of the organisms mentioned in the options can cause this except Corynebacterium minutissimum.

Corynebacterium minutissimum causes a localized infection of the stratum corneum called erythrasma. It presents as superficial skin lesions in the axilla and groin. This is a lipophilic corynebacterium and can be grown readily in media containing 20% fetal calf serum.

Sporotrichoid lymphocutaneous infection classically presents as superficial cutaneous lesions following cutaneous inoculation or trauma and progresses along dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics. Also known as nodular lymphangitis, the most common causes include:

  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Nocardia brasiliensis
  • Mycobacterium marinum
  • Leishmania brasiliensis

Option A: Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. It causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. Microscopy shows asteroid bodies. It can be seen as an oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. Itraconazole is the drug of choice for treatment.

The image below shows asteroid bodies.

Option C: Nocardia brasiliensis is a gram-positive aerobic bacteria frequently found in the soil and infection may be exogenous. Cutaneous infections can present as local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions. It causes mycetoma which is a localized chronic, granulomatous condition involving subcutaneous and deeper tissues, commonly affecting the foot. It presents as a tumor with multiple discharging sinuses.

Option D: Mycobacterium marinum is a non-tuberculous mycobacterium that causes swimming pool granuloma. The lesion begins as a papule which breaks down to form an indolent ulcer. It usually occurs after abrasions and is seen on the prominences like elbows, knees, ankles, or toes.

questions.text:
Which of the following rules of law are associated with insanity?
  1. Durham's rule
  2. Curren's rule
  3. Ashley's rule
  4. Murphy's rule
questions.solution:
Durham's rule and Curren's rule are laws associated with insanity.

Durhams's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Curren’s rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

In India, the law of Criminal responsibility is under BNS Section 22 (Section 84 IPC) It states that "Nothing is an offense which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or what he is doing is either wrong or contrary to the law”. This is slightly different from McNaghten's rule followed in Britain.

M'Naghten's rule states that every man is to be presumed to be sane, and possesses a sufficient degree of reason to be responsible for his crimes until the contrary is proved.

Other rules to assess the criminal responsibility of insane persons:

  • The Irresistible Impulse
  • Federal rule or American Law Institute test (ALT)
  • The Brawner rule

Note: Ashley's rule is used to differentiate males and females based on the combined length of the manubrium and sternum. It is considered to be a male sternum when the combined length is >149 mm, while if the combined length is <149 mm, then it is considered female. 

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text: Hereditary angioedema is due to a defect in which of the proteins mentioned below?
questions.solution:
Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, their deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin.

Clinical features include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, which may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stress. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

The main inflammatory mediator responsible for these symptoms is bradykinin. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator formed by the cleavage of kininogen, in the presence of the enzyme kallikrein. Bradykinin has the following effects:

  • Increases the vascular permeability
  • Causes contraction of smooth muscle
  • Dilates the blood vessel 
  • Mediates pain

Other options:

Options B and C: Decay-accelerating factor (DAF) and CD59 are two proteins that are linked by a glycophosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor to the plasma membrane. DAF prevents the formation of C3 convertases and CD59 inhibits the formation of the MAC. An acquired deficiency of the enzyme that creates GPI anchors leads to a deficiency of these regulators and excessive complement activation and lysis of red cells resulting in Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH).

During inflammation, C5a (Option D), C3a, and C4a, which are all cleavage products of their corresponding complement components, stimulate mast cells to release histamine. They have effects similar to those of mast cell mediators involved in anaphylactic reactions and therefore, are called anaphylatoxins. C5a is also chemotactic for neutrophils, monocytes, eosinophils, and basophils. Additionally, it activates the lipooxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in neutrophils and monocytes, resulting in the further release of inflammatory mediators.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of various types of Angioedema

Characteristic Features of Various Types of Angioedema

Clinical Presentation

C4 Level

C1-INH Function by Chromogenic Assay

C1-INH Level

 

 

C1q Level

Hereditary Angioedema (HAE)

Inherited defect in the gene for C1-esterase inhibitor. Autosomal dominant: patients have one normal, one abnormal gene

Type I

Recurrent episodic angioedema and abdominal attacks without urticaria. Onset in childhood or young adulthood. 75% have family history. Note that attacks may be oestrogen dependent in this group as well as the Type III form.

Usually LOW

NORMAL

Type II

Usually LOW

NORMAL or HIGH

Type III

Family history present in most cases, onset after childhood. Female patients predominate and attacks often appear to be estrogen-dependent.

NORMAL

Acquired Angioedema (AAE)

Condition not inherited but due to other underlying disease. C1-esterase inhibitor is low due to consumption

Type I

Onset age variable; symptoms same as HAE. No family history, may be associated with underlying lymphoproliferative disease.

 

Usually LOW

LOW

Usually LOW, May be NORMAL

Type II

Onset at variable age; symptoms indistinguishable from HAE. No family history, often associated with an autoantibody that binds to C1-INH.

NORMAL

Angioedema occurs through allergic mechanism and does not involve C1-INH.

ACE Inhibitors

Pseudoallergic (NSAID) or non-allergic (ACE) inhibitors Angioedema may start at first use. Acute onset of well-demarcated subcutaneous non-pitting edema of the face or hands

NORMAL

NORMAL

Angioedema with Urticaria

Angioedema is accompanied by urticaria. Does not usually involve C1-INH.

Allergic AE

Exposure to food, venom, latex, drug, or environmental allergen. May include anaphylaxis

May be LOW or NORMAL

NORMAL

 

NORMAL OR LOW

Long-lasting urticaria with tenderness. Vascular Damage. With Hypocomplementemic Urticarial Vasculitis, the CH5O is usually LOW and so are classical pathway components.

Frequently chronic and relapsing, often occurs with urticarial. Consider test for chronic urticarial (CD203c)

NORMAL

questions.text: On Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining oocysts of size 8-10 μm cysts are visible. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The organism with oocysts of size 8-10 μm is Cyclospora.

Cyclospora is a coccidian parasite.The sporulated oocysts are infectious to humans. They reside in the enterocytes in the small intestine. The infection causes prolonged diarrhea, abdominal pain, and vomiting, which is more severe in immunocompromised individuals.

On a wet mount of the feces, oocysts are seen as red spheres when stained with acid-fast stain. Sporulated oocysts of Cyclospora are 8-10 μm in size, round, and contain 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites. Treatment is by giving cotrimoxazole twice daily for seven days.

Other options:

Option A: Oocysts of Isospora are 23-36 μm, oval, and contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites. They are uniformly acid-fast.

Option B: Sporulated oocysts of Cryptosporidium are spherical, 4-5 μm in size, and acid-fast. It is implicated in causing traveler's diarrhea and chronic persistent diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are Cryptosporidium hominis and Cryptosporidium parvum. 

Option D: Microspora oocysts are 2-4 μm in size, oval to cylindrical in shape with a polar filament. Spores are gram-positive and acid-fast. They cause a wide range of opportunistic infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: The dose-response curve for three drugs in the same tissue is shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Efficacy of drug A is more than that of drug B.
Potency of drug B is more than that of drug A.
Drug A & drug B are agonists.
Drug C is a non-competitive antagonist.

questions.solution:
In the given image, drug A & drug B are agonists. 

Drugs that bind to physiological receptors and mimic the regulatory effects of endogenous signaling compounds' are agonists. Drugs that are only partially as effective as agonists are partial agonists.

The efficacy of a drug indicates the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. A drug with high efficacy is a full agonist, eliciting a full response at some concentration. A drug with a low intrinsic efficacy will be a partial agonist. Drug A & drug B are agonists (Option C) that have the same efficacy (Option A), although, at different concentrations.

Drug C does not produce a full response at any concentration, making it a partial agonist. In the presence of a full agonist, a partial agonist behaves like a competitive antagonist (Option D).

When two drugs produce equivalent responses, the drug whose dose-response curve lies to the left is said to be the more potent since it requires a lower dose to produce the same effect. Drug A & drug B produce the same action and level of response in the tissue. The curve of drug A on the left indicates that it produces the same response at a lower concentration, making it more potent than drug B (Option B).

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue. Investigations revealed the following: Hb, 5 gm %; MCH, 24; low MCV; leukocytes, 11,000/uL, and platelets, 5 lakhs. The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis?

Normal values:

  • Mean cell volume (MCV): 90 ± 8 fL
  • Mean cell Hb (MCH): 30 ± 3 pg
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a 35 year old woman, her iron profile and peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia are suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia (IDA).

IDA is an example of microcytic hypochromic anemia. The causes of IDA can be inadequate diet, impaired reabsorption, increased requirement and increased blood loss.

The manifestations of IDA depend upon the underlying cause. In general, IDA presents with koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic changes in the tongue, gastric mucosa, malabsorbtion and pica (craving for consumption of non-edible materials)

Peripheral smears show small and pale red cells typically described as microcytic (reduced MCV) and hypochromic (enlarged zone of central pallor). Poikilocytosis can be seen in the form of elongated red cells, known as pencil cells. Target cells can be found in cases of severe IDA.

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are:

  • Low hemoglobin and hematocrit
  • Low serum iron and ferretin
  • Increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)
  • Hepcidin is low (decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis)

IDA is treated by giving oral and parenteral preparations if iron or packed cell transfusion depending upon the severity of the anemia.

Option A: Megaloblastic anemia is defined by a high MCV

Option C: Thalassemia presents much earlier in infancy, with reduced MCV and a normal/increased RBC count

Option D: Essential thrombocytosis is characterized by isolated rise in platelet count (>450,000) along with normal hemoglobin, hematocrit and iron stores.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with the following skin manifestation of a disease associated with Raynaud phenomenon. What is the manifestation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic sclerosis, and the skin manifestation shown is a salt-and-pepper appearance.

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of unknown etiology, complex pathogenesis, and variable clinical presentations. It is associated with significant disability and mortality. Virtually every organ is affected. Thickened and indurated skin, called scleroderma, is the distinguishing hallmark of systemic sclerosis.

Cutaneous features of systemic sclerosis:

  • Raynaud phenomenon, with the typical white discoloration of the fingers caused by vasospasm and bluish discoloration of the fingertips
  • Loss of pigmentation except in the perifollicular areas is known as the salt and pepper appearance of the skin, which is mostly seen in the upper back, chest, and scalp
  • Puffy fingers in early disease
  • Sclerodactyly and sclerosis extending proximal to the metacarpophalangeal joints with or without contractures 
  • Vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences
  • Loss of fingertip pulp
  • Severe flexion contractures
  • Facial features include expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and a beak‐like nose  
 
Other options:
 
Option A: Poikiloderma is a skin disorder characterized by hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, wrinkling following atrophy, and telangiectasias. It is seen in ionizing radiation-damaged skin and dermatomyositis.
 
Option C: The hair in the amelanotic lesions of vitiligo can sometimes lose color and become white. This is called leukotrichia.
 
Option D: Vitiligo is characterized by depigmented macules that have sharp demarcation. It is due to the loss of melanocytes.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history

The lower two-thirds of the esophagus often develops a rubber-hose–like an inflexibility.

questions.text: What does the given ECG show?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows P-pulmonale.

P-pulmonale is characterized by an increase in P-wave amplitude ≥2.5 mm. Occasionally, a prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1 is seen. It is caused by overload in the right atrium and often occurs with severe pulmonary disease.

It is of limited sensitivity and specificity in the diagnosis of right atrial enlargement.

Causes of right atrial enlargement are:

  • Pulmonary diseases, such as pulmonary embolism, asthma, COPD, and chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension.
  • Congenital heart disease, such as pulmonary valve stenosis, atrial septal defect, Ebstein's abnormality and Fallot's tetralogy.
  • Tricuspid stenosis or regurgitation.
  • Cardiomyopathies, such as arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy/dysplasia (ARVC/D).

The image below shows the ECG changes in atrial enlargement.

questions.text: A patient who had undergone appendicectomy 2 days ago presents with severe abdominal pain. On exploration, there is a collection of blood in the abdomen. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during surgery?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the ileocolic artery should have been ligated.

The right colic, superior rectal and superior mesentric arteries are not ligated during an appendicectomy.

When an appendicectomy is performed, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix. Otherwise, postoperative hemorrhage can occur. 

The appendicular artery usually arises directly from the ileocolic artery and descends posterior to the terminal ileum to enter the mesoappendix. The artery runs very close to the free margin of the mesoappendix and terminates in multiple small branches that supply the appendix.

The terminal part of the artery lies on the wall of the appendix and may become thrombosed in appendicitis, resulting in distal gangrene or necrosis.

The blood supply of the appendix is shown in the image below.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about interleukin-12?

1. Increases production of interferon-γ
2. Inhibits T cells
3. Inhibits B cells
4. Produced by macrophages
questions.solution:
The true statements are that interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon-γ (IFN-γ).

IL-12 is produced by dendritic cells and macrophages. Its principle actions are to promote the production of IFN-γ, which drives TH1-type responses and further stimulates macrophage activation. It also promotes the differentiation of CD4+ T-cells to Th1 cells.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs is a β2 agonist?

1. Dopexamine

2. Dipivefrine

3. Fenoldopam

4. Mirabegron
questions.solution:
Dipivefrine and dopexamine are β2-adrenergic receptor agonists.

Dipivefrine causes a decrease in aqueous production and increases outflow. It was used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension but has since been replaced.

Dopexamine is a synthetic analogue related to dopamine with activity at D1 and D2 receptors as well as at β2 receptors. It is used in patients with severe congestive heart failure, sepsis, and shock.

Other options:

B. Fenoldopam is a peripheral D1 agonist with moderate affinity for α2-adrenergic receptors. It is a rapidly acting vasodilator that is used in severe hypertension.

D. Mirabegron is a β3-adrenergic receptor agonist which is used for bladder incontinence. Activation of this receptor in the bladder leads to detrusor muscle relaxation and increased bladder capacity. This action prevents voiding and provides relief for those with an overactive bladder and urinary incontinence.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of sildenafil?
questions.solution:
Sildenafil acts by inhibiting phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) and is used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction.

PDE-5 inhibitors cause the accumulation of cGMP in the corpus cavernosum, which leads to the relaxation of smooth muscles of penile arteries that fill the corpus cavernosum, thereby improving erectile function in patients with erectile dysfunction.

In addition to erectile dysfunction, sildenafil can be used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Adverse effects include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, blue-green tinting of vision, and erections lasting more than 4 hours.

Sildenafil is contraindicated in patients using nitrate vasodilators, which could result in dangerously low blood pressure.

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

questions.text:
A chronic smoker presents to the clinic with shortness of breath. A mass is noted at the lower lobe periphery of the lung. A diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma is made. The biopsy will be positive for:

1. Thyroid transcription factor-1 
2. p40
3. Napsin A
4. Chromogranin
questions.solution:
The biopsy of adenocarcinoma of the lung will be positive for thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation or mucin production by the tumor cells. It is associated with tobacco smoking, but less so than other histologic subtypes. It is the most common subtype in non-smokers and is associated with the loss of function of EGFR, ALK, ROS1, MET or RET genes.

The majority express TTF-1, which is a protein required for normal lung development. Napsin A is a new marker and is more sensitive and specific than TTF-1 in the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma.

Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns: acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid. The lesions are small and are usually located in the periphery.  At the periphery of the tumor there is often a lepidic pattern of spread, in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septa. 

Clinical features usually have an insidious onset. The incidence is usually at age 50 or more. The major presenting complaints are cough, weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea.    

Other options:

Option B: p40, along with p63 is a marker for squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Option D: Chromogranin is a marker for small cell carcinoma of the lung.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true?

1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
2. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs.
3. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs.
4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.solution:
The true statements are 1,4.
 
Sympathetic efferents are distributed extensively all over the body whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to head, neck, and trunk regions.
 
Sympathetic fibers travel short distances to the sympathetic ganglionic chain, before finally synapsing and then have a long course to supply the target organs. Parasympathetic fibers travel a longer distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs.
 
Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. A motor unit comprises a motor neuron and a group of skeletal muscle fibers it innervates.

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss?
questions.solution:
The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

In human beings, there is a loss of water through vaporization from the respiratory tract (300–400 mL) and diffusion from the skin (300–400 mL). This is called insensible water loss. It is about 50 mL/hour. This insensible water loss via the skin is independent of sweating and occurs in people without sweat glands as well.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position?

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.solution:
The upper part of the right inferior lobe is prone to aspiration in the supine position. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

The posterior segment of the right superior lobe and the superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most commonly involved lung sites when aspiration occurs in a recumbent patient.

The location of aspiration depends on the position of the patient since it is gravity-dependent. Aspiration while standing leads to infiltration of bilateral inferior lobes because of larger and more vertical corresponding bronchi, the middle lobes and the lingula.

Aspiration of contents into foreign substances into the bronchial tree, usually oral or gastric contents, produces aspiration pneumonia. Chemical (gastric acid) injury or bacterial infection complicates the condition.

questions.text: The following image shows an instrument used to estimate hemoglobin levels. What does it measure?
questions.solution:
The instrument in the image is Sahli's hemoglobinometer and is used to measure acid hematin levels of a given blood sample. 

In Sahli's method, oxyhemoglobin is converted to acid hematin with the action of dilute hydrochloric acid (N/10 HCl). The brown color of the acid hematin is matched to its intensity with a standard brown glass comparator in a visual colorimeter called Sahli’s colorimeter.

Sahli's method is a simple bedside test and is cost-effective. However, it has some disadvantages which include visual errors, inability to measure other forms of hemoglobin, fading of the comparator over time, and the color of acid hematin fading quickly.

questions.text:
Oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of which of the following cranial nerves?

A. III
B. IV
C. VI
D. VIII
E. VII
questions.solution:
The oculocephalic reflex or doll's eye reflex is used to assess the integrity of the cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII.

It is a brainstem reflex examined by observing the the motion of eyes during the sudden rotation of the head of the patient by the examiner. It is done in both directions laterally, followed by flexion and extension. In a normal positive reflex, the eyes move conjugately in the opposite direction of the movement of the head to maintain their position in space.

The reflex has afferents in the vestibular nerve (VIII) that relay to the brainstem nuclei and bring about conjugate eye movements through the oculomotor nerve (III) and abducens nerve (VI).

A negative reflex occurs in any of the above cranial nerve palsies or brainstem injuries, where the eyes show no movement or movement in the same direction as head movement. This is used to assess brainstem reflexes in a comatose patient as a criterion of brain death.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Hamman’s sign can be elicited in pneumomediastinum. It is a crunching or clicking sound that is synchronous with the heartbeat and best heard in the left lateral decubitus position.

Pneumomediastinum:

The main causes of gas/air in the interstices of the mediastinum are

  1. Alveolar rupture, perforation or
  2. Rupture of esophagus/trachea/bronchi,
  3. Dissection of air from the neck or abdomen into the mediastinum.

Clinical features include severe substernal chest pain (may or may not radiate to the neck and arms) and subcutaneous emphysema over the suprasternal notch.

The examination may reveal subcutaneous emphysema in the suprasternal notch with Hamman’s sign.

Chest x-ray confirms the diagnosis. No treatment is usually required, but inhaling high concentrations of oxygen will help absorb the mediastinal air. Needle aspiration can be performed if mediastinal structures are compressed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a breast lump with no skin changes or induration. On histology, there was a fibroadenoma appearance. Which of the following categories does it fall under?
questions.solution:
Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor in a 25-year-old woman with no skin changes and no indurations and is categorized as BIRADS 2.

Fibroadenoma is a form of aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI), and it is the most common cause of a breast lump in women aged 15–25 years.

It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth or lobular, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). The histopathology shows the proliferation of intralobular stroma, and the epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted (intracanalicular pattern).

USG is done to confirm the diagnosis. A biopsy is needed if USG shows atypical features or the age of presentation is above 25 years.

The image below shows the histology of fibroadenoma:

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy

questions.text:
The steps in the management of snake bite include:
  1. Loose tourniquet
  2. Debride to avoid the spread
  3. Kill the snake
  4. Hospitalize for anti-venom administration 
  5. Immobilization
questions.solution:
The management of snakebites includes immobilization and administration of anti-snake venom (ASV) after hospitalization.

Immobilization is done to minimize the spread of the venom. Hospitalization, followed by ASV administration is the definitive management of snake bites.

Measures that can be taken in the case of snakebite:

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap) on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. A pressure of 50 to 70 mm Hg is maintained.
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting.

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb 
  • Do not attempt to kill or catch the snake as it may be dangerous.
  • Administration of ASV locally at the wound site.
  • Herbal/local remedies

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that arises from the marked part.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the abducens nerve that arises from the pontomedullary junction.

In the groove between the medulla and pons, abducens, facial, and vestibulocochlear nerves emerge arranged medially to laterally.

The abducens nerve is the 6th cranial nerve that arises from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction, passes through Dorello's canal, and enters the cavernous sinus where it lies lateral to the internal carotid artery. It then enters the orbit through the common tendinous ring in the superior orbital fissure to supply the lateral rectus.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the limbic system?

1. Amygdala
2. Hippocampus
3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
The amygdala, hippocampus, and thalamus are all a part of the limbic system.

The limbic system refers to the interconnected neuronal circuit in the basal part of the brain that controls emotional behavior and other vegetative functions such as body temperature, the osmolality of the body fluids, and the drives to eat and drink and to control body weight.

The limbic system includes the following:

  • Subcallosal gyrus
  • Cingulate gyrus
  • Parahippocampal gyrus
  • Hippocampal formation
  • Amygdaloid nucleus
  • Mammillary bodies
  • Anterior thalamic nucleus
  • Hypothalamus

The connecting pathways for this system comprise the alveus, the fimbria, the fornix, the mammillothalamic tract, and the stria terminalis.

Related Pearl: Components of limbic system

questions.text:
Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below.

HBsAg positive
Anti-HBc IgG positive
Anti-HDV IgM positive
Titer of HBV DNA - 7.4 X 108 
Titer of HDV DNA - 4.1 X 104 

Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV superinfection over coinfection?
questions.solution:
As anti-HBc IgG antibodies are representative of a chronic hepatitis B infection, their presence may be indicative of an HBV/HDV (hepatitis B/hepatitis D) superinfection.

HDV superinfection occurs when a person who is already chronically infected with HBV acquires HDV. The infection of HDV on chronic hepatitis B can accelerate the progression to severe disease in all ages. HDV superinfection accelerates progression to cirrhosis almost a decade earlier than HBV mono-infected persons. 

HBV/HDV coinfection occurs when a person simultaneously becomes infected with both HBV and HDV. In acute hepatitis, simultaneous infection with HBV and HDV can lead to mild-to-severe hepatitis. The signs and symptoms typically appear 3–7 weeks after the initial infection and include fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, dark urine, pale stools, jaundice (yellow eyes), and even fulminant hepatitis. However, recovery is usually complete.

Diagnosis of HDV infection is by detecting high levels of anti-HDV immunoglobulin G (IgG) and immunoglobulin M (IgM). It is confirmed by the detection of HDV RNA in serum, and their levels are not helpful in differentiating between acute and chronic infections. There is no specific treatment for HDV infection. Pegylated interferon alpha may be used (with limited efficacy).

Anti-HBc IgM and anti-HBs IgM are indicative of acute phases of hepatitis B and, therefore, more likely to be associated with coinfection of HDV.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++
